I feel, we could extend that interface rather than adding some new interface but, you could wait for others.

I don't have preference on this.
reading that commit message, it sounds like a whole different type of redundancy so I'd rather not mix uses.
Acknowledged
The interface name doesn't quite match what I have in the design.  After the final name is decided on I can update each as necessary.

Is there a particular reason why you're not utilizing https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Object/Enable.interface.yaml?

I believe it's essential to set it as readonly to prevent a DBus client from enabling/disabling redundancy, as the implementer of this interface will have a method to control the redundancy feature. Is this the rationale behind your decision?

Two reasons not to use enable
1. It isn't a unique interface in the system, so any code wanting to see if redundancy was enabled what have to know to look at some hard coded object path just for that interface.  The typical way to find an interface is to use the mapper to tell you the object path.
2. I think these properties belong on the same interface anyway.


Correct, only the application that implements this interface will be able to modify its value.

I believe eventually we'll need a 'redundancyDisabledReason' property that contains an enum of why system can't be redundant, so the app would also handle that.

>It isn't a unique interface in the system, so any code wanting to see if redundancy was enabled what have to know to look at some hard coded object path just for that interface. The typical way to find an interface is to use the mapper to tell you the object path.

Agree

>I believe eventually we'll need a 'redundancyDisabledReason' property that contains an enum of why system can't be redundant, so the app would also handle that.

Yeah we need that details anyway to understand why the redundancy is disabled.
nit: Do we want "Unknown" here?  That tends to be the keyword we use elsewhere.
Done
Do we need a default service name?  Everyone should use mapper to find this, right?
I thought it was so we have a constant that even the server could use when it claims the bus name.  If it's rather for clients I will remove.

It appears that it doesn't align with the proposed object path outlined in the design document:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/70233/3/designs/redundant-bmc.md#328

I feel, this interface path more readable, shall we update the design doc if you agreed?
I also have a comment up above about how they don't match, but I like this one better. After everyone  agrees on which one is best I will update the other use.
Ok
Done
Same as mentioned above

Why'd you end up with both (instance and namespace)?  I'd think you only need a single string.  Usually namespace is used for cases where there is something under it (path segments) but it seems like you just have a singular instance?

I think I just misunderstood the documentation. Will remove the namespace.

Also, do you think it would be better to put this on /xyz/openbmc_project/state/bmc0 (where bmc state manager is) or have it be on a unique path?
updating to match design doc.
Clarified in the above comment.
huh, I guess markdownlint changed again?
or maybe i just needed to rebase
Just one doubt, otherwise looks good to me.
I’m not quite following this. How are signals sent from one BMC to its sibling BMC over DBus? is it DBus over TCP Or did you mean it’s implementation-specific?

the idea is that the daemon holds the D-bus interface for the sibling watches this and handles on that sibling Dbus api appropriately.  Which is https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/73944/3/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/State/BMC/Redundancy/Sibling/API.interface.yaml#77

full flow is:
1) rbmc daemon on BMC A emits this Heartbeat signal.
2) API daemon on BMC A gets it to the sibling (in our case, write to cfam)
3) API daemon on BMC B gets it from sibling and puts summary into that dbus property (i.e. is hearbeat going)
4) rbmc daemon on BMC B can read that to know if BMC A is good
ah ok, I missed to look at the above Gerrit change, I don't know how I missed from my review inbox..will check on it..Thanks
Got it.
Acknowledged
will change this to match how State.BMC has it.
Done
Why do we need to emit this on dbus?  It isn't obvious who the consumer is.
I mention it in the design doc here https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/70233/9/designs/redundant-bmc.md#430.  It's so the daemon that talks to the sibling can get it.

I thought the daemon that talks to the sibling creates this interface?  I guess it creates "Sibling"?

Why not just have that application determine its own Heartbeat timer?  Seems a little awkward to have one repository/daemon hold the timer just to send a signal to a different daemon to take action?  What is the advantage of having this be a dbus-signal and not an internal timer in the "talks to sibling" daemon?

It's that the management daemon on one BMC wants to know if the management daemon on the other is in a good state.
The path is:

rbmc-manager0 -> sibling-daemon0 <-----> sibling daemon1 -> rbmc-manager1
